Taking the Headphones Off

As part of the application process for Dev Bootcamp, I took a quick test to determine my personal thinking style. It’s based on the research of Anthony Gregorc which is theorized into the Gregorc Mind Styles. These mind styles can help illuminate, not only how a particular person thinks, but also how they learn.

Sometimes you get stuck on a challenge or project and need just a little (or a lot) of help to find a solution. Over the course of my last few weeks, I’ve found that I have been bookmarking links left and right to resources that I can refer back to when needed. Rather than having them all locked up in my bookmark bar, I decided to share them here. Both for ease of access and also to help out my fellow tech learners and explores.

June 15, 2014Ernie Salazar  •  Comment Reading time ~2 minutes

Caring is Pairing

One of the primary take aways of my experience at Dev Bootcamp so far, has been based around pair programming. It’s a means which allows, usually two programmers to work cooperatively seeking solutions and completing projects. It’s so vital to our success that we’re encouraged to pair often and even have minimum pairing session quotas to meet. It’s a great tool in our educational growth but also a common practice in many of today’s tech companies.

Riding the Rails

We’ve talked some over the last few weeks about Ruby, a dynamic object-oriented programming language, and some of the ways it can be used. One of the more common applications is to pair it with Rails, a productive web-application framework. The combination of the two creates Ruby on Rails, more commonly known as Rails.

Now, as this phase comes to a close and I’ll soon be immersed in Phase 1, I wanted to update my site to be more functional, easier to manage and overall, more professional.
